Dear Mr. HANNAH :
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please note that violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the MISEP and
your contract.

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact Kari Muntean at 734-395-0920.
Sincerely,
Tracey Ventola, Licensing Consultant

INVESTIGATION:
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4158R 400.4158 Intervention standards and prohibitions.
Section Rule 158. (1) A child caring institution shall establish and follow written
Description policies and procedures that prohibit the following forms of intervention:
(a) Any type of physical punishment including, but not limited to: (i)
(ii) Hitting or striking, throwing, kicking, pulling, or pushing a youth on
any part of their body.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Staff inappropriately grabbed youth by the collar of her shirt or her
shoulders and inappropriately removed her from the unit doorway and
brought her back into the unit.
Investigation This complaint was received on 12/19/2022 and jointly investigated with
the DHHS Specialist. The complaint noted the following:
Youth A (15) is a court ward who resides at Vassar House. Youth
Worker 1 and Youth Supervisor 1 are staff members at the facility.
Youth A has a safety plan in place and is supposed to be supervised
due to self-harming behaviors. This morning Youth Worker 1 and Youth
Supervisor 1 were supervising Youth A and were trying to maintain a
line of sight on Youth A. Youth A walked out of the cafe and Youth
Worker 1 and Youth Supervisor 1 followed Youth A and attempted to
walk her back to her unit. Youth A sat down and refused to go back to
her unit. Youth Worker 1 and Youth Supervisor 1 inappropriately
grabbed Youth A by the collar of her shirt or shoulders and
inappropriately moved her from the unit doorway and brought her back
into the unit. Youth A does not have any visible marks or injuries.
4

There are no videos of the incident. Youth Worker 1 and Youth
Supervisor 1 have both been sent home for the day.
I interviewed Youth A at the facility on 12/21/2022, jointly with the
DHHS Specialist. Youth A has lived at Vassar House for the past six
months. Youth A lives on unit 3 and after breakfast she refused to
return to her unit. Youth A said she sat down on the ground, crossed
legged, not far from her unit. Youth A reported Youth Worker 1 and
Youth Supervisor 1 were both present. Youth A said Youth Supervisor
1 dragged her by her shirt collar into the unit. Youth A indicated Youth
Supervisor 1 was on the side of her and dragged her by the side of her
collar. Youth A reported she was dragged a short distance just inside
the doorway. Youth A reported she was dragged a few seconds and
was not hurt. She denied any marks or injuries on her body from the
incident. Youth A denied Youth Worker 1 touched her. Once inside the
doorway of her unit Youth A continued to sit cross legged on the floor
by the front door. Youth B and Youth C were posted by the front and
back doors to deter Youth A from leaving the building. Posting was
described by Youth A as when a youth sits in front of the door to keep
another youth from leaving the building. The youth posted are
reportedly not allowed to touch the youth attempting to leave and are
only a physical deterrent. Youth A denied that she is afraid of any staff.
Youth A reported no one was outside when this occurred.
I interviewed Youth Worker 1 at the facility on 12/21/2022, jointly with
the DHHS Specialist. Youth Worker 1 has worked as a youth care
worker for eight and a half years. She works first shift from 7am until
3pm and on Monday's she works 6am until 2pm. Youth Worker 1
reported on the day of the incident she worked from 6am until 2pm.
She woke the children up and Youth A had requested a sweatshirt and
socks which were provided to her. Youth Worker 1 reported Youth A
was doing well that morning and lined up for breakfast without any
issues. Youth Worker 1 said when they went to breakfast Youth A's old
unit (unit 1) was also eating breakfast and this upset Youth A as she
wanted to go back to living on unit 1. Youth A walked out of the cafe
and Youth Worker 1 walked out behind her and asked her what was
going on with her. Youth A said she wanted to go back to unit 1. Youth
Worker 1 took Youth A back to the café. When they attempt to go back
to her unit, Youth A sat down cross legged on the ground outside.
Youth A sat on the ground for approximately 20 minutes refusing to go
back into her unit. Youth Worker 1 said she talked with Youth A trying
to get her to go inside. Youth Worker 1 reported Youth Supervisor 1
was standing behind Youth A and grabbed Youth A under her arms and
slid/pulled Youth A into unit 3. Youth A was left sitting inside the
doorway of the unit and two youth were posted at each exit. Youth
4

Worker 1 reported the youth were posted at the doors for approximately
five minutes and then all the youth went to school including Youth A.
Youth Worker 1 said “I was shocked when she did it” regarding how
Youth Supervisor 1 pulled Youth A into the unit. Youth Worker 1 denied
that she has ever seen Youth Supervisor 1 put her hands on a youth
previously. Youth Worker 1 said she felt it was “sort of aggressive as it
happened so fast”. Youth Worker 1 did not tell anyone about what
happened and left to go take kids to wrap presents.
Youth Worker 1 indicated posting is used when there is not enough
staff to post by the doors. The youth post in front of the exit doors by
standing or sitting on a chair in front of the door. The youth are not
allowed to touch anyone trying to leave threw the door. Youth Worker 1
indicated Supervisors decide if they are going to post and who is going
to post at the doors.
Case Manager 1 was phone interviewed on 1/3/2023. She has been an
employee with Vassar House for 22 years in many capacities. She is
currently a case manager at Camp 1. Case Manager 1 reported that
she was working on unit 3 and Youth A refused to go back to her unit
after breakfast. Case Manager 1 took the rest of the girls back to the
unit and Youth Worker 1 and Youth Supervisor 1 were with Youth A
who was sitting crossed legged on the ground outside refusing to go
into unit 3. Case Manager 1 observed the door to the unit open and
close as the staff were trying to escort Youth A into unit 3. The door
opened again and while Youth Worker 1 and Youth Supervisor 1 were
escorting Youth A she sat down. Case Manager 1 reported Youth
Worker 1 and Youth Supervisor 1 pulled Youth A by the collar of her
sweatshirt and her shoulders into the building. Case Manger 1 reported
Youth A did not say anything and did not indicate she had been harmed
or injured. Case Manager 1 reported they pulled Youth A about 4-5
feet. After Youth A was inside the unit, youth were posted at the front
and back door to deter Youth A from leaving the unit. Case Manager 1
reported posting is when a youth or adult sits at the exit doors. The
person posting should not touch the youth and they are just a visual
block. Posting is used when they have concern of truancy. Case
Manager 1 said they sometimes use staff to post if enough staff are
working. Case Manager 1 reported that posting is utilized at all units at
Vassar House but is not used at another of the organization’s facilities.
Case Manager 1 indicated she left the unit shortly after the incident and
reported the incident to a higher up staff member who reported it to
Centralized Intake.
I interviewed Youth Supervisor 1 via phone on 1/5/2023 with the DHHS
Specialist. DHHS Specialist was with Youth Supervisor 1 onsite, and
4

this writer was present by Teams. Youth Supervisor 1 has been
employed at Vassar House for four years. She reported she worked a
third shift the night of the incident. She was in the cafe passing
medication and Youth A kept walking in and out of the café. Youth A
was upset because her old unit was also in the cafe eating breakfast
and getting medication. Youth A verbalized she wanted to return to her
old unit. When Youth A left the cafe Youth Worker 1 followed her
outside. Youth Supervisor 1 indicated Case Manager 1 called her to let
her know Youth A was outside with Youth Worker 1. Youth Supervisor
1 could not immediately assist as she was passing medication. Youth A
and Youth Worker 1 returned to the building and Youth A was standing
next to Youth Supervisor 1 saying she would not return to her unit, and
she wanted to stay with Youth Supervisor 1. Youth Supervisor 1 said
she told Youth A she couldn't stay with her as she was passing
medication. Youth Supervisor 1 told Youth A she could not move her
back to unit 1 as this was not something she had the power to do.
Youth A then walked out again heading to her unit and then stopped
and turned to go to her old unit. Youth A then sat down on the ground
and was scooting backward trying to get to unit 1. Youth Supervisor 1
said she went outside and was trying to talk with Youth A to get her to
go to her unit. Youth A then picked up something off the ground and
took off running. Youth Supervisor 1 did not know what she picked up
off the ground. Youth Supervisor 1 felt Youth A's behavior was a risk as
she had just come off a safety plan. Supervisor 1 indicated she hooked
her arm in Youth A's left arm and Youth Worker 1 hooked her arm in
Youth A's right arm and they began to escort Youth A to unit 3. Youth A
was reportedly walking and then when the door opened to go inside,
she tried to sit down. Youth Supervisor 1 said she told her she had to
go in. Youth Supervisor 1's arm was reportedly still linked with Youth
A's, and she grabbed Youth A's sweatshirt in the bicep area and pulled
to assist with moving her inside the doorway. Youth A sat inside the
doorway once pulled inside. Youth Supervisor 1 denied dragging Youth
A but said she used enough force to get her inside the building. Youth
Supervisor 1 indicated "I may have pulled her excessively to get her
into the unit". Youth Supervisor 1 reported they were outside with Youth
A approximately 30-45 minutes. Youth Supervisor 1 said she did not
see Youth Worker 1 pull or use any force when escorting Youth A, into
the building. Youth Supervisor 1 denied that Youth A had any injuries or
was hurt. Youth Supervisor 1 posted youth at the front and back door
as only one staff left working on the unit. Youth Supervisor 1 went to
unit 4 and Case Manager 1 left. Youth Supervisor 1 reported posting
“has always been here. It is done by staff and youth, but it is better
when youth do it as kids go right past staff as they know we can't touch
them”. Youth Supervisor 1 reported Youth A was no longer on a safety
plan the day of the incident. Safety plans are kept in a binder for each
4

youth in the unit. Staff are required to sign the safety plan to verify they
have reviewed it.
Youth B was interviewed onsite with the DHHS Specialist on 1/12/2023.
Youth B resides in the same unit as Youth A. Youth B reported that
Youth A was refusing to go into the unit and Youth Worker 1 and Youth
Supervisor 1 were talking to her trying to get her to go inside. Youth B
indicated Youth A walked away several times. Youth B reported Youth
A swung at Youth Supervisor 1 and kicked her. Youth Supervisor 1
blocked the kick and attempted hit. Youth B saw Youth Supervisor 1
trying to guide Youth A into the unit. Youth A dropped to the ground in
the entrance doorway. Youth A's back was to the unit, and she was
facing out the doorway. Youth A was reportedly kicking, and Youth
Supervisor 1 was walking towards Youth A and Youth A was scooting
back into the unit. Youth B reported Youth Supervisor 1 blocked and
walked. She reported Youth Worker 1 did not assist in anyway but was
trying to grab Youth A's feet unsuccessfully. Youth B said Youth
Supervisor 1 did not push or pull Youth A. Youth B denied she was
posted at the front door or any door. Youth B could not recall who
posted at the doors. Youth B reported Youth A was not hurt by staff and
that Youth A hurts staff and she runs off all the time. Youth B described
posting as standing in front of the door and being able to move back
and forth to block a youth from leaving. Youth B has seen other kids
post and they push and hit the youth trying to leave. Youth B reported
Youth A had gotten a rock and was self-harming with the rock. Youth A
was scratching her wrist with the rock, and she tried to swallow the
rock. Youth B reported Youth A has a history of having items that she
self-harms with. When youth have items, they should not have, and are
keeping them concealed the youth are asked to "pop". Popping
described by Youth B is pulling your bra or waistband out away from
your body and it pops back onto your skin to dislodge concealed items.
Youth C was interviewed with DHHS Specialist at the facility on
1/12/23. Youth C reported Youth A walks off from the unit a lot and staff
follow sometimes. Youth C reported Youth A is gone from the unit for
one to one and a half hours sometimes. Youth C reported Youth A
walked out of the cafe and Youth Worker 1 and Youth Supervisor 1
were talking to her outside trying to get her to come back in, but Youth
A kept walking away. They got her back to the unit and Youth A
attempted to walk off, so Youth Worker 1 and Youth Supervisor 1 pulled
her back in. Youth Supervisor 1 was pulling Youth A by the arms into
the middle of the unit. Youth A was reportedly on her back and then sat
up. Youth Worker 1 was at Youth A's feet. Youth C said Youth
Supervisor 1 was behind Youth A and had Youth A's hands up above
her head. Youth Supervisor 1 had her hands on Youth A's wrists and
was pulling her into the unit. Youth Worker 1 was reportedly in front of
4

Youth A pushing her feet against Youth A's feet. Youth A did not have
on shoes and Youth Worker 1 did have on shoes. Youth C reported she
also saw Youth Supervisor 1 grab Youth A by the collar/neck of her
shirt to keep her from leaving the building. Youth C said she never saw
Youth Worker 1 or Youth Supervisor 1 have their arms locked with
Youth A's. Youth C reported Youth A told her that staff hurt her by
pulling her into the unit. Youth C did not see any bruises or injures on
Youth A. Youth B and Youth E were posted at the doors. Youth C
reported Youth Supervisor 1 said she was done messing with Youth A
after the incident. Youth C reported she has seen Youth Supervisor 1
be aggressive with other kids who are no longer placed at the facility.
Youth C reported that Youth Supervisor 3 was there during the incident
and saw what happened.
Youth D was interviewed onsite with DHHS Specialist on 1/12/23.
Youth D reported that Youth A has been moved out of their unit
because she kept running out and needs one on one supervision.
Youth D denied seeing any interaction with Youth Supervisor 1 and
Youth A. Youth D indicated Youth Supervisor 1 is a good staff and that
she advocates for them. Youth D reported she has never seen any staff
harm Youth A. As a note, Youth D reported she was in the cafe and
overheard Youth Worker 2 bragging about beating up a kid. Youth
Worker 2 reportedly indicated she was sick and tired of Youth A's
“bullshit”, and she gave her a can of “whoop ass”. Youth A was
interviewed again on this date related to this information from Youth D.
Youth A reported Youth Worker 2 had worked in the unit yesterday and
a few days ago and Youth A indicated she had been telling Youth
Worker 2 she was going to beat her up. Youth Worker 2 responded to
Youth A's threats with "I don’t care". Youth A indicated she apologized
to Youth Worker 2 for saying she was going to beat her up. Youth A
denied that Youth Worker 2 put her hands on her and stated, "we are
getting along good". Youth A did not express fear of Youth Worker 2.
Youth Supervisor 3 was interview by phone with DHHS Specialist on
1/23/23. She denied being present during the incident with Youth A
being brought into the building, stating her shift was just starting, and
she has no knowledgeable about what occurred. Supervisor 3 was
aware of the process youth are calling popping. She described this as a
process they use to search a youth when they hide things in their
clothes. The youth are asked to undress to their shorts and t-shirt and
then have to pop their bra and waistband. Youth Supervisor 3 reported
posting is done with staff when there is a risk of a youth going AWOL
from the building. She reported only staff post. She said posting was
done by staff and youth up until the past month or two.
4

Youth Worker 2 was interviewed via phone with the DHHS Specialist on
1/24/23. Youth Worker 2 has been employed with Vassar House since
October 2023 as a Youth Worker. Youth Worker 2 reported she is
familiar with Youth A and that Youth A acts out a lot and tells people
daily she is going to beat them up or that she going to beat some ass.
Youth A is reportedly a difficult youth at Vassar House, and she often is
on a one-to-one supervision and has a safety plan. Youth A also
frequently leaves the building multiple times a day. Youth Worker 2
indicated Youth A has told her she is going to beat her up and then
apologizes typically the next day. Youth Worker 2 said she knows this
about Youth A and this appears to be her pattern of behavior. Youth
Worker 2 reported she has never said she was tired of Youth A’s
bullshit. Youth Worker 2 reported she has never said she gave a can of
whoop ass to Youth A. Youth Worker 2 said staff do not like to be one
on one with Youth A as she is very difficult to supervise. Youth Worker
2 is familiar with the term pop. She has never had a youth do this but
heard it is done when youth come back from visitation. Youth Worker 2
shared they have to post as part of their jobs. She described posting as
one person at the front door and one at the back door to maintain line
of sight on the youth.
Throughout this investigation youth reported incidents of self-harming
events by Youth A and a lack of one-to-one supervision when
necessary for Youth A and other youth. There were allegations of youth
being told to break up a fight and aggressive behavior by staff with
youth. These allegations had been investigated previously or were
currently under investigation in Special Investigations 2023C000046,
2023C0000177, 2023C0000046, 2023C0229003, and therefore were
not investigated as part of this report.
Documentation reviewed as part of this investigation includes the
following, with applicable information outlined:
Original incident report witness statement authored by Youth Worker 1,
dated 12/19/2022. The report noted the following 'Youth A refused to go
back to her unit after breakfast and walked off from her group and went
outside. Staff walked behind her talking with her to come to the group.
Youth A was taken back to the cafeteria and SST was informed she
was refusing to return to her unit. Youth A then walked with group
towards her unit and when she got close to the unit she sat down on
the ground and said she was not going back to her unit. Staff stood
outside with Youth A for about 20 minutes. I guess the youth care
worker supervisor was frustrated at the time. She then pulled the client
into the unit and told two peers to post at the door’. X
4

Original incident report witness statement authored by Youth
Supervisor 1, dated 12/19/2022. The report noted the following: 'While
in the cafe passing meds Youth A was playing around and laughing at
the table. Prior to that she was having issues in the unit because she
didn't want to be in the unit she was moved to. Youth A left the building
and walked around for a while and then returned and I closed the cart
and talked to her. Youth A was getting escalated, and I talked to her
about why she couldn't move. I talked with her and got her to walk
back where the units were, and she turned as if she was going to unit 1.
I provided proximity between Youth A and going towards unit 1 by
standing in front of her trying to talk with her to go back to unit 3. I
placed my arm inside her arm and said, we can walk to the unit
together like this, so it doesn't look like you refused to go back. I could
probably help you not get much paperwork. Youth A said really and
then sat on the ground for about 20 minutes and then got up to run
away from units which I felt was unsafe due to her history and just
coming off a safety plan. I placed my arm inside her arm along with
YW1 and I opened the unit door as we were escorting her back to the
unit with the door open as we got halfway back in the door she began
to refuse to go back, and she sat on the floor, and I asked two clients to
post at the doors. Youth A sat on the floor in the hallway’.
Original incident report witness statement authored by Case Worker 1,
dated 12/19/22. The report noted the following, ‘after breakfast Youth A
refused to go back to the unit and went outside. Youth Worker 1 went
with Youth A, and I took the rest of the group to the unit. After a while
the door opened, and Youth Supervisor 1 and Youth Worker 1 were
trying to escort Youth A into the unit. Youth A turned and walked back
outside. At about 7:15am the door opened; Youth A was sitting down.
Youth Worker 1 and Youth Supervisor 1 got her by collar/shoulders and
dragged her into the unit while she was still sitting. Then I was told I
could leave my shift, so I did’.
Nurses Note dated 12/19/22. Youth A was seen by the staff nurse on
12/19/22. Youth states on report that she was pushed into her unit
yesterday evening and today. She then stated she couldn't remember.
After thinking about it for a minute, Youth A stated that last night staff
pushed her on both shoulders into the unit and this morning she was
sitting on the floor/ground so staff couldn't get a hold of her, and that
staff pushed her then grabbed the collar of her sweatshirt and pulled
her. Youth A denied any pain or discomfort. Nurse observed where
client stated staff touched her. There was no bruising, redness or open
areas present.
Medical documentation from Covenant MedExpress Frankenmuth.
Youth A was seen by Dr. Ayush Shrestha, MD on 12/19/22 for injury
4

due to altercation. She was released with no restrictions and no noted
areas of injury on the release papers.
Youth A safety plans: Youth A had a client safety plan from December
20, 2022-January 1, 2023, and one from January 1, 2023-January 30,
2023. The client safety plan outlined what makes Youth A feel unsafe,
what unsafe behavior looks like for her and how to keep herself safe.
Youth A also had a staff safety plan from November 1, 2022-November
23, 2022, and December 20, 2022, until January 30, 2023. The staff
safety plan outlined Youth A’s safety concerns -suicidal ideation,
making threats, self-care, isolating and ignoring redirection. Safety
based restrictions for Youth A included staff stay within 6 feet of Youth
A, only one SST will give Youth A her personal hygiene items, no client
will give Youth A anything, staff in bathroom speak to Youth A and to
have a safety blanket, but no clothes in shower.
BSM1 Policy & Procedure for TCI in Residential Program the TCI
interventions are non-violent and are used in such a manner as to not
be hostile or injurious. The approved restraint techniques are supine,
standing and small child restraint.
BSM Prohibited Interventions Policy This policy outlines interventions
that are prohibited by the facility. The use of physical discipline inflicted
in any manner is prohibited. Clients shall not be permitted to discipline
other clients. Staff cannot use interventions that will limit movement,
diminish sensory experience, limit personal freedom or cause personal
discomfort.
Maintaining Safety and Security-residential procedures for conducting
searches of clients. The procedure states that clients are searched
with a wand, their belongings are searched, and body pat downs are
used. Youth are pat down at admission, when returning from off
grounds or if there is a reasonable suspicion of possession of
contraband. The procedures for conducting searches does not explicitly
include popping of the youth’s bra and waistband.
Analysis The facility is in violation of the rule. Youth Supervisor 1 admitted to
using force to move Youth A into the building after she had dropped
weight and was sitting on the ground. Youth A reported she was pulled
into the building and several youth and staff indicated Youth Supervisor
1 pulled Youth A into the building. Pulling youth to get them where staff
want them to be is not in line with facility policy and is not permitted
under the rules.
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE: Several youth and staff reported the use of
popping as a form of search when youth have concealed items. The
4

use of this form of search should be added to the Maintaining Safety
and Security- residential procedures for conducting searches of clients
so that staff have a clear understanding of how to do these searches.
Conclusion Violation Established
Rule Code & R 400.4158 Intervention standards and prohibitions. Rule 158. (1) A
Section child caring institution shall establish and follow written policies and
Description procedures that prohibit the following forms of intervention:
(v) Peer-on-peer discipline.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation Staff have youth post at the doors and intervene when another youth is
threatening to AWOL or leave the building without permission.
Investigation During the investigation it was reported by youth and staff that they post
youth in front of the exit doors to deter a youth from leaving the building
who is threatening to walk out/AWOL.
Youth A was interviewed onsite on 12/21/22 with DHHS Specialist.
During the interviewed Youth A reported once she was inside the
building kids were posted at the doors. Youth A described posting as
two youth from her unit sitting on chairs in front of the doors to deter her
from leaving the building.
Youth B was interviewed on 1/12/22 with DHHS Specialist onsite.
Youth B denied that she was one of the youths who was posted at a
door during Youth A's incident. She described posting as standing in
front of the door to block a person from leaving. Youth B said they can
block with their body and can put up their hands to block the person
from running out. They can also block by moving from side to side in
front of the door. Youth B reported she has seen other kids push and
hit youth when they are posted at the door.
Youth Worker 1 was interviewed on 12/21/22 onsite with the DHHS
Specialist. While describing the incident with Youth A Youth Worker 1
reported they posted two youth at the exit doors. She reported posting
is a common thing they do when a youth is threatening to leave the
building. Posting is a practice done by staff and youth. Youth are
reportedly posted when they do not have enough staff to post at the
doors. Youth are not allowed to touch one another but they are
allowed to stand in front of the door to keep the youth from leaving the
building. Youth Worker 1 reported posting is part of the facility’s
training.
4

Youth Worker 2 was interviewed via phone with the DHHS Specialist on
1/24/23. Youth Worker 2 reported posting is what staff do to keep line
of sight. One staff stands at the front door and one at the back. Youth
are not allowed to post. This is reportedly done to deter the youth from
leaving the building, but they are not allowed to touch the youth should
they decide to walk out of the building.
Case Manager 1 was phone interviewed on 1/3/23. Case Manager 1

are attempting to leave but are a visual block. Case Manager 1
reported staff are told how to do this by Supervisor staff. She further

Youth Supervisor 1 was interviewed on 1/5/23 with DHHS Specialist.
Youth Supervisor 1 reported that once they had Youth A inside the

Youth Supervisor 3 was interviewed with DHHS Specialist on 1/23/23.
Youth Supervisor 3 reported posting is when a supervisor asks a staff
to sit or stand at the exits to keep youth from leaving the building.
Youth Supervisor 3 said youth and staff were used to post up until

Documentation reviewed:
BSM Prohibited Interventions Policy This policy outlines interventions
that are prohibited by the facility. The use of physical discipline inflicted
in any manner is prohibited. Clients shall not be permitted to discipline
other clients. Staff cannot use interventions that will limit movement,
diminish sensory experience, limit personal freedom or cause personal
discomfort.
Analysis The facility is in violation of the rule. Staff and Youths A and B
reported the use of posting youth to assist with youth attempting to
leave the building/AWOL. Youth are placed in front of doors to keep
their peers from leaving the building when the facility is short staffed.
This practice sets up youth to be in a position of power over one
another as well as a position to providing discipline or redirection to

other youth. Youth B has seen youth push and hit one another when

Conclusion Violation Established
